The Houthis are drowning: floods in Hodeidah

Loss of life and great property damage following torrential rains that caused floods in the last day in Hodeidah province in Yemen, which is controlled by the Houthis.

According to initial estimates, about 45 people were killed and many more are missing. Many houses were destroyed.

Yesterday the Palestinian Ministry of Health in Gaza published information on approximately 32,000 of the approximately 39,000 dead in the Strip.

According to the updated data, about 32.9% of the dead are children, 18.5% are women, about 8.6% are elderly and about 40% are men aged 18-59.

I will mention in this context that in the last two weeks, the Palestinian Ministry of Health in Gaza admitted that it had updated the ages of some of the dead who had moved from the category of adults to the category of children....
They explain this "miracle" by saying that some of the "men - children" were killed a long time before they arrived at the hospital, where they were registered as dead over the age of 18. That is, according to them, those dead were killed shortly before the age of 18 and arrived at the hospital after they would have turned 18, so they should be registered as children in the updated database.

The impact of Yahya Sinwar's appointment as Hamas Political Bureau Chief on the ongoing war

As someone who has closely followed Yahya Sinwar for many years, I believe Sinwar is far more competent than Ismail Haniyeh in every aspect. In my view, even in his previous role as the leader of Hamas in Gaza, Sinwar surpassed Haniyeh in skills and ambitions. Haniyeh was more of a symbolic leader than the actual "President of Hamas." Sinwar has always been more dominant, sharper, more ambitious, saw further and aimed higher... perhaps too high. Sinwar believes that he can achieve things others think are imaginary or impossible - this is largely how, in collaboration with Mohammed Deif, the ambitious plan for the October 7th massacre was conceived. To implement such a plan, to think of it in the first place, one needs to be an extraordinary person, with sophisticated and exceptional thinking, great courage, insensitivity, and a certain degree of madness - all of which Sinwar possesses. Haniyeh, less so.

Last night, I wrote that I think the move to appoint Sinwar as the head of Hamas's Political Bureau brings us one step closer to ending the war. Let me explain.

First, one of the main goals of this move, in my view, is to relieve the pressure on Qatar. The Americans exerted significant pressure on the Qataris, who host the Hamas leadership abroad, to pressure Hamas into agreeing to a hostage deal. This current move neutralizes the American pressure on Qatar - the decision-making center has now entirely shifted to the Gaza Strip. This also eliminates the need for "back and forth" on important decisions regarding the war between Hamas leaders abroad and those inside the Gaza Strip. 

The Gaza chapter of Hamas is now making the decisions, and the "full responsibility" lies on its shoulders. Effectively, Yahya Sinwar is the Gaza chapter, and he is now responsible for managing the war. To a large extent, the "keys to ending the war" lie within a small area, easily accessible to Israel and under constant physical Israeli pressure.

In my opinion, Hamas has taken an "all in" approach regarding the war and what is happening in Gaza, while isolating the territory (of the Gaza Strip). Gaza's fate is now in its own hands. I am convinced that Hamas leaders considered the realistic possibility of Yahya Sinwar being eliminated in Gaza when they unanimously decided to appoint him. 

Perhaps, in their eyes, such an event could allow them to embark on a new path, retreating from positions Hamas is currently stuck in. Positions that do not allow for the end of the fighting.

This could close the chapter of October 7th, a product of the Gaza Strip designed by Yahya Sinwar and Mohammed Deif, and could end in Gaza when those who conceived it meet their fate there. It would allow Hamas to place all of the responsibility onto the architects of the attack and change the course of the movement's future once they are both out of the picture. In such a case, Sinwar and Deif would take with them to the grave the responsibility for the events of October 7th, for better or worse, from Hamas's perspective. There is a poetic justice in this.

This dramatic change is a result of the assassination of Haniyeh in Tehran, which that could not have occurred in Qatar due to the American protection that Qatar enjoys. The cards have been reshuffled, and now there is an opportunity to break the deadlock.

##
Beyond that, I will note that Palestinian media and channels refer to all Israelis as rapists مغتصبون in the context of "land occupation" - the Israelis according to their ideology are raping the Palestinian lands - this is a deep-rooted expression in Palestinian society.

The towns and cities in Israel are often referred to as rapists مغتصبات - "towns that rape the Palestinian land"

The root of the word, غصب, has a significant place within several aspects of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. It is important to internalize this and act from the understanding of how it is perceived on the other side.

The video that was leaked last night to Channel 12, with the accompanying text of the reporter, is resonating widely in Palestinian and Arab media and on various channels with the caption:

جريمة مروعة أمام الكاميرات... جنود الاحتلال يغتصبون أسيراً فلسطينياً في سجن "سديه تيمان"

"A despicable crime before the eyes of the cameras... occupation soldiers rape a Palestinian prisoner in Sde Teiman prison."

##
This, in my opinion, has far-reaching consequences for the Palestinian argument regarding the denial of the acts of rape committed by Hamas terrorists on October 7.

I will explain: here Israel distributes visual documentation of what the reporter claims are acts of rape but does not distribute documentation of its claims regarding acts of rape by Hamas terrorists on October 7th.
This arms the deniers of the atrocities of October 7th.
